title: How to Fix Breyer Horses

methods.name: Fixing It without the Broken Part

steps.headline: Get some "bondo" body car filler and sand it to the shape of the leg.
Paint it to match the horse.
steps.description: Gloss paints are probably the best but if you have a horse painting kit use those.

steps.headline: Seal the leg with a good brand of clear coat top finish.
steps.description: This is optional: if the horse is already shiny, this will not make the leg stand out as much.

steps.headline: Attach the leg to the horse.
steps.description: You can just smooth it on like clay.

steps.headline: Let it sit for a couple hours until it is completely dry.

methods.name: Fixing It with the Part and Glue

steps.headline: Take some new nail polish remover and put an adequate amount on a cotton ball or Q-tip.
steps.description: Apply to the break and the horse.

steps.headline: Wait until the plastic gets soft and mold-able.
Gently push the break and the horse together.
Wait for them to set.
steps.description: After a couple minutes, you should be able to let go of the pieces and they should stay together.

steps.headline: The break is not nearly cured.
steps.description: Wait several hours for the plastic to completely bond together. Keep it in a position so when it dries, the part is in the position you want it to be in.

methods.name: Fixing it with the Part, Glue, and a Nail

steps.headline: Get both pieces.
steps.description: Having both is important. Use rubbing alcohol and clean both pieces thoroughly.

steps.headline: Gently mark both sides with a sharpie in the middle.
Use a small screw and drill/poke holes in both pieces.
Use plastic glue to secure a very small nail or pin with one end in the horse and the other end in the broken piece.
steps.description: In other words, connect the horse's piece with the nail, secured by glue.

text: Fixing It without the Broken Part Get some "bondo" body car filler and sand it to the shape of the leg.  Paint it to match the horse. Gloss paints are probably the best but if you have a horse painting kit use those. Seal the leg with a good brand of clear coat top finish. This is optional: if the horse is already shiny, this will not make the leg stand out as much. Attach the leg to the horse. You can just smooth it on like clay. Let it sit for a couple hours until it is completely dry.  Fixing It with the Part and Glue Take some new nail polish remover and put an adequate amount on a cotton ball or Q-tip. Apply to the break and the horse. Wait until the plastic gets soft and mold-able.  Gently push the break and the horse together. Don't force it on though. Wait for them to set. After a couple minutes, you should be able to let go of the pieces and they should stay together. The break is not nearly cured. Wait several hours for the plastic to completely bond together. Keep it in a position so when it dries, the part is in the position you want it to be in. Fixing it with the Part, Glue, and a Nail Get both pieces. Having both is important. Use rubbing alcohol and clean both pieces thoroughly. Gently mark both sides with a sharpie in the middle.  Use a small screw and drill/poke holes in both pieces. Make sure they fit perfectly. Use plastic glue to secure a very small nail or pin with one end in the horse and the other end in the broken piece. In other words, connect the horse's piece with the nail, secured by glue. Do not touch the horse for at least 3 days. After those days, test the 'injury' and make sure the leg is aligned well. Re-apply glue if necessary. Make sure it looks clean.
